column1: Richmond Hill (2016 population: 195
column2: 022) is a city in south-central York Region
column3: Ontario
column4: Canada. Part of the Greater Toronto Area
column5: it is the York Region's third most populous municipality and the 28th most populous municipality in Canada.

column1: Richmond Hill has seen significant population growth since the 1990s. The city is home to the David Dunlap Observatory telescope
column2: the largest telescope in Canada.

column1: == History ==
The village of Richmond Hill was incorporated by a bylaw of the York County Council on June 18
column3: coming into effect January 1
column4: 1873. In September 1956
column5: the Ontario Municipal Board approved its elevation to Town status
column6: effective January 1
column7: 1957.The Regional Municipality of York was established by Bill 102 An Act to Establish the Regional Municipality of York of the provincial parliament
column10: and coming into force on January 1
column11: 1971. The act expanded Richmond Hill's borders
column14: Vaughan Township and King Township into Richmond Hill
column17: 000 acres (110 km2) and the population from a little over 19
column19: 000.  The town grew to encompass the communities of Gormley
column29: Oak Ridges and Richvale. While Richmond Hill was a prosperous
column31: many of the outlying areas annexed were far more rural
column33: no water mains or sewers and no streetlights
column34: and the time needed to bring municipal services up in these areas
column35: combined with residual unequal tax assessments caused considerable conflict in the municipal politics. Policing was taken over by the York Regional Police
column36: but fire protection remained with Richmond Hill
column37: whose firefighting force quickly grew. Having hired its first full-time employee in 1967
column38: it had fourteen full-time employees by 1971.

column1: Yonge Street through Richmond Hill expanded from two lanes to four in 1971
column2: relieving congestion on what was known as "Ontario's worst stretch of highway".The Richmond Hill Dynes Jewellers softball team was the 1972 Softball World Champions. The Royal Canadian Air Farce was recorded at the Curtain Club Theater in Richmond Hill for its first 5 seasons on radio
column3: beginning in 1973.  The Air Farce returned for an anniversary recording in the 1990s. Also in 1973 was the centennial of the town's incorporation as a village
column4: and the town set up a number of celebratory activities
column5: including a beard growing contest
column6: commissioning a centennial song
column8: a street dance and the unveiling of a historic plaque honoring the town's founding in front of the municipal offices.  June 27 was officially declared Russell Lynett Day
column10: only the third in its existence.  1973 also saw the sale of the last of the original rose-growing greenhouses in Richmond Hill.  Development had led to increasing property taxes and the H.J. Mills greenhouses relocated to Bayview Avenue and Elgin Mill Road.  The site of the greenhouses was developed as a subdivision.  The fast-growing town set aside significant areas for parks
column11: with five new parks dedicated in 1973
column12: and two more in 1974.  The Richmond Hill Historical Society was founded in 1973.  The society was dedicated to preserving the history of Richmond Hill and raising awareness of the town's history.  Their first action was to restore a 150-year-old house

column1: As the 1970s went on
column2: the population growth of Richmond Hill remained large.  In 1976
column3: home prices in Richmond Hill were among the highest in Canada. By this time
column4: the town council was split over whether to keep expanding rapidly.  The deadlock over a fifty-five house subdivision named Springmills Estate led to one councilor saying that it was not the reform council it was dubbed
column5: but a "deformed council".  Other housing projects faced similar problems as councilors debated many things
column6: including the need for affordable housing and the encroachment of homes into the farmland and the Oak Ridges Moraine.

column1: GO train service was extended to Richmond Hill in 1978
column2: officially opened on April 29
column3: 1978 by Bill Davis.Growth in Richmond Hill slowed towards the end of the 1970s
column4: with M.L. McConaghy Public School closing in 1979 due to dropping enrollment.  At the same time
column5: Richmond Hill began to make official plans for future land development.  The first official plan concerned a 700-acre (2.8 km2) industrial park at Leslie Street and Highway 7 named Beaver Creek.  A commercial area within the park spread into the hamlet of Dollar.  The plan was rejected
column6: however
column8: and Richmond Hill was the first municipality in Ontario to have its official plan rejected outright by the board.  The whole affair was subject to much controversy in the community
column9: although the town council eventually declined to appeal the decision.

column1: When the new council convened in 1980
column2: led by new mayor Al Duffy
column3: the town remained without a development plan.  The council hired civic planner Peter Walker to produce a new official plan.  By September 1981
column4: the new plan was drafted
column5: with limited development of northern Richmond Hill
column6: industrial development centred in the south-east part of town and commercial centres remaining along Yonge Street.  The plan was approved in July 1982 by the Ontario Municipal Board.

column1: A clash over the use of the land in Langstaff
column2: known as the Langstaff Jail Farm erupted in 1982 between Richmond Hill and Toronto
column3: which owned the land.  The 632-acre (2.56 km2) plot of land had been acquired by Toronto in 1911
column4: and was unused in 1982.  Toronto's plans for development clashed with those of Richmond Hill over the balance of industry and residential development
column5: with Richmond Hill favouring more industrial development.The rose business left Richmond Hill in June 1982
column6: with the closure of H.J. Mills florists. Mills died in 1980
column7: leaving the company to his son
column9: combined with increasing property taxes in the growing city made the business unprofitable.  A 1984 contest organised by The Liberal had readers submit entries for a new town slogan.  The town council chose three of the submissions which residents then voted on
column11: a little nicer" became Richmond Hill's new town slogan.

column1: Richmond Hill's growth continued during the 1990s
column2: fueled in significant part by immigration
column3: with many businesses opened on Highway 7 around Leslie Street serving the new Chinese Community that formed there. In the early 90s
column4: Statistics Canada named Richmond Hill as Canada's fastest-growing community.On March 25
column6: the Richmond Hill Council passed a motion to change the title of Richmond Hill from 'town' to 'city'.

column1: == Politics ==
The city's motto is En la rose
column2: je fleuris (French for "Like the rose
column3: I flourish")
column4: reflecting either the motto of the Duke of Richmond
column5: or the fact that the city was a centre of rose-growing in the early 20th century. At that time
column6: it was known as the "Rose Capital" of Canada. A more recent motto for Richmond Hill is A little north

column1: Richmond Hill is the only municipal Canadian government to have light pollution laws in place due to the presence of the David Dunlap Observatory.
In June 2013
column2: the city's council passed a bylaw to ban the number 4 from new street numbers because it is considered to be bad luck by some Asian cultures.

column1: === Governance ===
The city is governed by the Richmond Hill City Council
column2: which operates on a Mayor-Council system with six Ward Councillors and two Regional Councillors
column3: plus the Mayor.  The council serves a four-year term
column4: after which a new council is elected by qualified electors in Richmond Hill.

column1: The council derives its authority primarily from the Municipal Act
column2: 2001 and the amendments of the Municipal Law Amendment Act
column3: 2006.  Richmond Hill is a Lower-tier municipality and has the roles and responsibilities of that position.  The municipality has a wide purview relating to the interests of the municipality and its residents to develop and maintain policies
column4: practices and procedures through the issuing of bylaws relating to highways
column5: transportation systems apart from highways
column6: waste management
column14: economic development and the licensing of business.  The city is also responsible for maintaining its finances in order to provide relevant services and for maintaining an official plan to guide development.

column1: === Elections ===
Elections for municipal offices are held every four years in conjunction with other municipal elections in Ontario. Elected positions include mayor
column2: regional and local councillors and ward councillors (for six different wards) on the Richmond Hill City Council
column3: as well as trustees for the York Region District School Board
column4: the York Catholic District School Board and for Conseilleres (school trustees) for the Conseil scolaire de district du Centre-Sud-Ouest and Conseil scolaire de district catholique Centre-Sud.  The mayor and regional and local councillors also serve on York Regional Council.

column1: == Culture ==
=== Arts ===
The Richmond Hill Public Library system has four library branches.The Richmond Hill Centre for the Performing Arts offers theatre productions
column2: concerts
column3: comedy
column4: and other shows in a multi-purpose space that includes a 631-seat auditorium.Housed in a restored cottage from the 1840s
column5: the Richmond Hill Heritage Centre offers an exhibit of local history and has a number of educational programs.

column1: === Recreation ===
Richmond Hill has 166 parks
column2: under the Town of Richmond Hill Parks Department in the Recreation & Culture Division
column3: of which most are small urban parks and 544 hectares of undeveloped natural area for recreation. The largest such park is Richmond Green Sports Centre and Park which includes several baseball diamonds
column4: two ice skating rinks
column5: a 300-person amphitheatre and a skateboard park.The City also has a total of six public swimming pools
column6: including an indoor wave pool. Each summer
column7: the city features a concert series entitled "Concerts in the Park"
column9: such as children's music and "The Beach Boys" and are held at Mill Pond Park
column10: with some Sunday concerts at Richmond Green Park.The city is also home to the Richmond Hill Country Club
column12: and the Bloomington Downs Golf Course.

column1: Richmond Hill was awarded the National Communities in Bloom award in 2003
column2: with a special mention about the city's floral displays.In September 2009
column3: Alias Grace Park was opened to honor Margaret Atwood's novel's depiction of the city in Upper Canada prior to John A. Macdonald becoming Prime Minister.

column1: ==== Sport clubs ====
Richmond Hill Curling Club
== Demographics ==
The 2016 Census recorded a population of 195
column3: an increase of 5.1% from 2011. Median age as of 2016 was 42.4
column4: slightly higher than the Ontario median age of 41.3. In 2016
column5: Visible minorities make up 60.0% of the population.According to 2016 Census data
column6: English is the mother tongue of 36.3% of the residents of Richmond Hill. Native speakers of Cantonese make up 11.6% of the city's population
column7: closely trailed by those of Mandarin (11.1%) and Persian (9.8%). Following are Russian (5.0%)
column10: 50.0% of the city's population adheres to Christianity
column11: mostly Catholicism (25.5%). Those who practice non-Christian religions adhere to
column15: Buddhism (2.8%) and Hinduism (2.4%). Those who do not have a religious affiliation account for 26.4% of the population.

column1: == Economy ==
According to the city's website as of 2011
column2: Richmond Hill is an affluent community with more than 52% of families reporting incomes of greater than $70
column3: 000 and over 31% of households reporting incomes greater than $100
column4: 000. The average household income in Richmond Hill is $100
column5: 900 which is 34% higher than the Canadian average and 26% higher than the provincial average. Based on the 2006 Census
column6: 42.62% of families in the City of Richmond Hill earned over $100
column7: 000 and over. The employment rate of the city is 66.36% with the most prevalent occupations being in the business
column8: finance and administration and management sectors. The 2006 Census showed that the unemployment rate is very low at 3.77%
column9: compared with the 7.4% unemployment rate across Canada during the time of the Census.The 1990s and 2000s were periods of strong economic growth for Richmond Hill; In 1999 industrial
column10: commercial and institutional growth was valued at $88.9 million
column11: up from $67.9 million in 1998.  The economic growth of 1999 won the city's economic development department three provincial awards from the Economic Developers Council of Ontario.  The border between Richmond Hill and Markham is a rapidly growing area for information technology and high-tech industry  with over 1
column12: 000 such businesses located along their border in 2000.Most businesses in Richmond Hill are small businesses
column13: with more than half of all employers in the city having four workers or less. The city is home to the corporate headquarters of Acklands Grainger Inc.

column1: == Education ==
The York Region District School Board operates 27 public elementary schools in Richmond Hill
column2: as well as 5 secondary schools: Alexander Mackenzie High School
column3: Bayview Secondary School
column4: Langstaff Secondary School
column5: Richmond Green Secondary School and Richmond Hill High School.  Students in schools in the York Region District School Board have scored above the provincial average on the Assessment of Reading
column6: Writing and Mathematics
column7: Primary Division (Grades 1–3) and Junior Division (Grades 4–6) since their introduction in 2002.  The board's students in academic math streams have performed above the provincial average on the Grade 9 Assessment of Mathematics every year since its inception in 2002
column8: while those in applied math streams were below the provincial average in 2002–2005
column9: and above the provincial average from 2005–2007.

column1: The York Catholic District School Board operates 13 Catholic elementary schools in Richmond Hill. It also operates two Catholic secondary schools
column2: St. Theresa of Lisieux Catholic High School and Our Lady Queen of the World Catholic Academy.There are also four private primary schools located in Richmond Hill and five private secondary schools
column3: including Holy Trinity School
column4: Richmond Hill Christian Academy
column5: Discovery Academy
column6: Toronto Montessori Schools
column7: and Richmond Hill Montessori & Private Elementary School.Post-secondary education services are provided to the residents of Richmond Hill by several post-secondary educational institutions in Toronto
column8: some of which have satellite campuses in nearby communities.

column1: Former Governor General Michaëlle Jean was a guest at the opening ceremony of a school named after her
column3: the Michaëlle Jean Public School.

column1: == Communities ==
Carrville
Dollar
Gormley
Lake Wilcox
Langstaff
Temperanceville
=== Other Neighbourhoods ===
==== Oak Ridges ====
Oak Ridges is an unincorporated community to the north of Richmond Hill's downtown and south of Aurora.
Historically it had a post office from 1851 to 1930s.Oak Ridges was annexed by Richmond Hill in 1971. It is largely residential
column2: with most commercial development located along Yonge Street. The city developed around Lake Wilcox
column3: the largest lake in the area and a community within Oak Ridges
column4: and has continued to expand slowly since its annexation. In the 1990s
column5: Oak Ridges experienced moderate growth
column6: which has spurred environmental action and anti-development movements by numerous organizations. Population has grown significantly as a result of development initiatives along Bayview Avenue. The Oak Ridges Community Center was built and completed in June 2012 to accommodate community demand.

column1: ==== Bayview North ====

Bayview North is a residential area along Bayview Avenue from Elgin Mills Road East to Major Mackenzie Drive. Western branch of the Rouge River runs through as well as Beaver Creek. Bayview Secondary School is located within Bayview North.
==== Doncrest ====

Doncrest is a small residential area along and east of Yonge Street just north of Highway 7. The area is located on crest of the Don River tributary German Mills Creek. Chinese businesses located along Highway 7 from Bayview Avenue are located here and ties with those around East Beaver Creek area.
==== Elgin Mills ====
Elgin Mills is an area around Yonge Street from Gamble Road to Elgin Mills Road. A business park
column2: Elgin Mills Business Park is located in the southeast. Overall a residential area served by Upper Canada Place and Elgin Mills Square at Yonge and Elgin Mills Road. Yonge-Bernard Terminal is a York Region Transit hub.

column1: The historic community once had a steam grist mill
column2: toll booth and inn at the corners of Elgin Mills Road and Yonge Street. The community existing prior to the establishment of a post office in 1900 and home to Newton Tannery before 1870 but business dwindled and reverted in the late 20th century as a residential suburb of Richmond Hill.

column1: ==== Headford ====

Headford was established as a postal village in 1856 and home to Methodist Church that opened in 1850. A brief oil fever in the 1860s but the area declined by the early 20th century. Headford once had saw (F. Eckhardt farm) and grist (John Burr farm) mills along Beaver Creek. Headford is now mainly a business park area bounded by Major Mackenzie Drive
column2: Leslie Street
column3: Highway 404 and 16th Avenue.

column1: ==== Hillsview ====
Hillsview is home to David Dunlap Observatory with residential homes now surrounding the observatory where it once were farms.
Beverley Acres is a smaller residential area within Hillsville at southwest corner of Yonge Street and Major Mackenzie Drive.
==== Mill Pond ====
Mill Pond is a park located in the mid-region of Richmond Hill that is surrounded by heritage homes. The pond once powered a sawmill located here in the 1800s.
==== Richvale ====
Richvale is two residential areas in the southwest end of Richmond Hill divided by Carrville Road and bounded by Yonge Street and Bathurst Street:
North Richvale-Yongehurst - area north of Carrville Road
South Richvale - area south of Carrville RoadHillcrest Mall is the main commercial hub of the communities. Richmond Hill Golf Club is located in the south end.
Historically the area had several saw mills next to ponds along the Don River but now have disappeared and filled in.
==== Yonge Street ====
The old downtown Richmond Hill (also known as the historic Village of Richmond Hill) is considered the strip of Yonge Street between Major Mackenzie in the south and Richmond Heights in the north.
The new theatre was opened in 2009 and provides a modern venue for live performances.
==== Bayview Hill ====
Bayview Hill is a subdivision located on the northeast side of Bayview Avenue and 16th Avenue. Built in the early 1990s
column2: the subdivision contains large expansive homes.

column1: ==== East Beaver Creek (Beaver Creek) ====
Richmond Hill's current commercial hub is located near Leslie Street and Ontario Highway 7
column2: where it borders Markham's AMD headquarters. Built in the early to mid-1990s
column3: the area is serviced by Highway 404
column4: York Region Transit
column5: and Buttonville Airport. The current City Hall was moved to that location in 1994.

column1: Southern Richmond Hill is home to the city's industrial and business region housing most of the city's hotels
column2: as well as the main commercial area of the city's Chinese community. The northern part of city is considered to be Old Richmond Hill as it is a historical area. Central Richmond Hill is a very commercial area
column3: housing multiple malls
column4: plazas and entertainment buildings
column5: such as theatres and restaurants. The northernmost part of the city is mostly farm land
column6: though it is slowly being developed.

column1: During the 1990s
column2: Chinese immigrants primarily from Hong Kong moved to Richmond Hill
column3: where they set up businesses and shops catering to the community. Many shops and restaurants were established in suburban-style shopping malls and plazas
column4: such as Times Square
column5: along a stretch of Highway 7 between Bayview Avenue and Leslie Street.

column1: ==== Jefferson ====
Historic Jefferson is named for Jonathan Jefferson who settled in Lot 59 and established a store and post office in 1840.Jefferson is a newly developed neighbourhood
column2: with housing begin to occupy in 2007. Jefferson Side Road is a major thoroughfare in the neighbourhood. Jefferson includes a large area
column3: roughly bounded by Gamble Road in the south
column4: Bathurst Street in the west and Bayview Avenue in the east. The community includes a residential subdivision namely Jefferson Forest
column5: located in the southeast portion of the community.

column1: Tower Hill is a smaller area in the south end of Jefferson and served by Tower Hill Road.
==== Windham ====
Windham was an early settlement along Yonge Street north of Elgin Mills to Jefferson Side Road.
Named for the British Secretary of War William Windham
column2: the area was settled in 1798-1799 by French emigres These royalist lead by Joseph-Geneviève
column3: Comte de Puisaye did not stay long and many would end up leaving the area. By 1814 most of these settlers had left.Henri Quetton de St. George
column4: French-born son of Laurent Quetton St. George (1771-1821)
column5: whom acquired land here in 1798
column6: built his estate
column8: around 1847 and is now part of Lake St. George Conservation Area. St. George's family either died or left Canada for France and was the only member to remain in the area. He died in 1896 and is buried at Temperanceville United Church.The Windham name would disappear after 1860s as Jefferson and Oak Ridges succeeded as new settlements. French Royalist Park in Jefferson is the only reminder of the French settlers.

column1: == Transportation ==
=== Road networks ===
The city of Richmond Hill is well serviced in terms of transportation facilities for a community of its size. The eastern border of the city is Highway 404
column2: a major highway that leads directly into the core of the City of Toronto via the Don Valley Parkway (DVP). Highway 404 also intersects with Highway 401 in North York
column3: which is one of the most traversed highways on the planet and is the principal east–west route in the Greater Toronto Area (GTA). The city's southern border is defined by the former Highway 7 and a parallel toll expressway
column4: Highway 407. The latter is a toll route and was designed as a bypass for the 401. The combined effect of these highways ensures that Richmond Hill is well integrated into Ontario's road network and has easy access for all road vehicles. The ease of accessing the city is threatened by increasing traffic due to growth in the region
column5: as the resulting commutes diminish the usefulness of the road network.

column1: === Public transit ===
Public transit within the city of Richmond Hill is on buses co-ordinated by York Region Transit (YRT).  In September 2005
column2: YRT unveiled a new rapid transit initiative entitled VIVA which provides enhanced bus service on major routes using vehicles capable of speeding up traffic lights to lessen the time they idle. Viva Blue
column3: Viva Purple
column4: Viva Orange
column5: and Viva Pink have stops in Richmond Hill. In addition
column6: YRT operates several feeder routes on secondary streets in the city.

column1: Commuter train service is provided to the city by GO Transit on the Richmond Hill line with two stations in the city
column2: Richmond Hill Station and Langstaff Station.  Langstaff Station is near the new Richmond Hill Centre Terminal of York Region Transit at Highway 7 and Yonge Street
column3: and is connected to it by a pedestrian bridge opened in March 2008. The Richmond Hill Centre Terminal is complete with enclosed heating areas
column4: payphones
column5: and credit card/debit card ticket purchasing machines.

column1: Owing to its proximity to Toronto
column2: there are plans to extend the TTC subway system to the intersection of Yonge and Highway 7. The project is in its preliminary planning
column3: design and engineering (PDE) phase
column4: with funding from the federal and provincial governments.

column1: === Other transportation ===
Richmond Hill is minimally serviced by other modes of transportation. Its landlocked situation inhibits any water transportation and it lacks an airport of its own
column2: though it does border on Markham's Buttonville Airport. The closest international airport is Pearson International Airport.

column1: == Geography and climate ==
Richmond Hill is bounded by Bloomington Rd. (Aurora town limit) to the north
column2: York Regional Road 7 (Vaughan city limit west of Yonge St.
column3: Markham city limit east of Yonge St.) to the south
column4: Bathurst St. (Vaughan city limit) to the west
column5: and Ontario Highway 404 (Markham city limit) to the east. Its southern limit is about 4 kilometres (3 miles) north of the Toronto city limit
column6: Steeles Avenue
column7: and approximately 20 kilometres (12 miles) north of the downtown core of Toronto. The city extends 14 kilometres (9 miles) north-south and 7 kilometres (3.5 miles) east-west.

column1: The predominant feature of the city's geography
column2: as its name suggests
column3: is its elevation above surrounding regions. Thousands of years ago during the last ice-age
column4: glaciers moving in a southerly direction amassed a considerable amount of earth in front of them which they carried forward as they grew. Gradually
column5: as the temperature increased the growth of the glaciers lessened and eventually they began to recede to what is now the polar ice cap. The earth that had been collected by the glacier's movement was left in place and the elevated region that remained comprises modern day Richmond Hill.

column1: The city itself is at a much greater elevation than other communities within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) and with the exclusion of areas closely alongside its borders
column2: the constituent of York region with the greatest height above sea level. The uneven melting of the glacier that formed the city has led to an extremely varied geography within the city's own borders
column3: leading to such features as kettle lakes
column4: minor tributaries and most notably the Oak Ridges Moraine.

column1: Kettle lakes are the result of glacier water getting caught in water-tight depressions in the land and are sustained by only rainfall in the immediate area. The City of Richmond Hill has many of these water bodies and its three largest in order of decreasing size are Lake Wilcox
column2: Bond Lake and Philips Lake. The kettle lakes are predominantly confined to the northern fringes of the city.

column1: Being elevated above the surrounding region
column2: precipitation in the city tends to flow outwards via the multitude of streams and rivers that flow through the city. Principally water flow is in one of two directions
column3: south to Lake Ontario or north to Lake Simcoe where they join up with larger tributaries that feed into the water bodies. Of note
column4: are the Rouge
column5: Humber
column6: and Don rivers which receive some of their flow from sources in the city.

column1: Perhaps the most important geographical feature of the City of Richmond Hill is the Oak Ridges Moraine. The moraine is a further elevated region of loose soil which comprises a significant portion (roughly the northern third) of the land area of the city. Its porous nature allows the collection and natural filtering of waters that flow through it which are then fed into multiple underground aquifers. While the city receives its water from the City of Toronto
column2: these aquifers are an important source for those with their own wells in addition to surrounding communities. The ability of the soil to hold so much water means that despite Richmond Hill's comparatively high elevation
column3: it has a very high water table which poses some problems to construction. The moraine is also host to a staggering amount of biodiversity and in recent years there has been a considerable amount of pressure applied to government to shield the area from development.  Consequently
column4: a considerable portion of Richmond Hill is subject to the Ontario Government's Greenbelt legislation.

column1: == Landmarks ==
Hillcrest Mall
column2: a large and popular shopping mall located on the northwest corner of Yonge Street and Carrville Road. It has 135 shops
column3: services
column4: and restaurants.

column1: The Emerald Isle motel on Yonge Street is known to display conservative rhymes and provocative quotes on their sign. These quotes usually relate to current events. The film
column2: Man of the Year
column3: starring Robin Williams was filmed at Emerald Isle Motel in late 2005. This motel also was featured in the film The Wrong Guy.

column1: The David Dunlap Observatory is home to the largest reflecting telescope in Canada.  The 74-inch (1
column2: 900 mm) telescope was the second largest in the world upon its construction in 1935.  The observatory was a research facility of the University of Toronto.

column1: The original Canadian burger chain Harvey's restaurant was opened in Richmond Hill in 1959 at the corner of Yonge Street and Observatory Lane. It was demolished in February 2012 and was replaced by the Xpression condominiums.
The City of Richmond Hill Municipal Office Building
column2: at 225 East Beaver Creek Road.  The building serves as the seat of government of the municipality.  Most of the city departments are located there
column3: and all public Council and Committee Meetings are also held in this building.

column1: The Richmond Hill Centre for the Performing Arts
column2: located in downtown Richmond Hill.
